Steps to Reproduce:

1.Open a git working directory.
2.Set the default eol to LF.
3.Converts the current file eol to LF.
4.Click the branch name in the lower left corner to switch the branch.
5.Then you will find all the files fol have become CRLF, but I just want LF.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Setting 'editor.action.triggerSuggest' as post completion command does show proposals
data.body:
Inspired by #31948:

The idea is that on a completion of a css property, code assist is activated again, to show the proposals for the property values.

- add 'editor.action.triggerSuggest' as post completion command
- invoke the completion proposal
- observe no completion window is opened

The triggerSuggest command is called, proposals are requested from the providers, but the operation is canceled before any suggestions are shown.
(cancel seems to come from SuggestController._onDidSelectItem)

data.title: Python debugger crashes instantly
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (b0c0634339c6f64a5c7f08b56fe732fb9154d3c4, 2017-09-15T05:24:23.107Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
python|don|0.7.0
cpptools|ms-|0.12.4
code-spell-checker|str|1.4.0



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open a folder.
2. create a python file, with these contents.
    ```
    x = int(input("Enter your x"))
    y = int(input("Enter your y"))
    z = x + y
    if z < 5:
        print("Addition to less than 5")
    else:
        print("More than 5.")
    print(z)
    ```
3. open debug launch. Use autocomplete to complete the external debugger launch.
4. press f5 in the python file. 
Expected: External terminal with printouts and such.
Actual: Terminal comes up very briefly, then boom, disappears. additionally, my default python file assosiation was at one point vs code, and a python file was launching in vs code as soon as I pressed f5 (Assumed to be used to spawn the debugger). I set python 3 as my default python handler, but still, not sure what's going on.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No Not applicable.

data.title: Clicking Inside a selected text does not clear the selection
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:23.027Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-autohotkey|sle|0.2.1


Clicking Inside a selected text does not clear the selection. An annoying bug, or useless feature... If you have a bunch of lines selected and you are done with it and want to continue working, you cannot simply click anywhere to clear the selection.  You have to click on a non selected line, clicking on the right of the selected text, in the whitespace simply wont do.

Long story short, the text should deselect no matter where I click, if I click inside the selected text, to perform a drag for example (which no one in his right mind would ever do anyway), the text should deselect upon left mouse release, because guess what, I'm done with this action! If you want to keep the selected text after a drag, then at least de-select if the click was not a drag

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1.Select a number of lines
2.Click the white space on the right or inside the selection. the text does not de-select

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: stdout/stderr not working in debug console
Explorer Viewlet: Allow to set to hidden by default

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1 (1.16.1) 27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.6 (16G29)

By default, VSCode allow users to hide/show custom explorer views, however its behaviour is to always show all explorer views on a newly opened project. Since not all extension developer make an option to hide these custom views, doing the hiding stuffs is quite tedious when work with a lot of projects. By allowing users to set their default showing preferences, this help reduce time to do unnecessary stuffs a lot.

data.title: Git commit message keymap for newline
data.body:
I often have >1 line commit messages. Or try to, when I remember that vscode is one of the only programs that uses _SHIFT_ + ENTER for a newline rather than _CTRL_ + ENTER. And that is ok, but an extremely useful addition would be to have a keymap point so that this could be changed. It would be much appreciated!

To be clear. I am referring to:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5379325/30526964-f6d5b300-9bd7-11e7-870d-3ba1863602ec.png)

data.title: terminal not painting until resize
data.body:
Windows
1.17.0-insider
b0c063

The [docker extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=PeterJausovec.vscode-docker) creates a lot of terminals when running docker commands.  I'm finding that the content of the terminal is not painting until i resize the terminal window.  It looks like the tool is hung, then you resize, then you can see the content.

Here's the docker build command running:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1487073/30525411-ebaf7924-9bba-11e7-8d0f-e65cae73a1c4.png)

Then resize, and now you can see the terminal:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1487073/30525416-0505ba5a-9bbb-11e7-9edf-6162a90197b9.png)

data.title: It is NOT an error to open a folder that isn't in a git repo
data.body: - VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:09.760Z) - OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063 - Extensions: Extension|Author (truncated)|Version ---|---|--- vscode-markdownlint|Dav|0.10.1 vscode-eslint|dba|1.3.1 xml|Dot|1.9.2 gauntlet|Mic|2.2.0 cpptools|ms-|0.12.4 csharp|ms-|1.12.1 PowerShell|ms-|1.4.3 code-spell-checker|str|1.4.0 --- Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open a folder that is not in a git repo Observe a big red error message from the git extension. Sorry, but opening a non-git folder is nothing to panic about and alert the user with an attention-getting alert that needs to be dismissed. This is normal functioning for an editor. When I click on the git widget, then it's time to tell me about it. Reproduces without extensions: No (Obviously a git extension issue)

data.title: Command D case sensitive option
data.body:
_From @xmattstrongx on September 16, 2017 14:50_

`Command D - Add Next Occurrence`

I have found this shortcut to be a nice substitute for a refactor command that you may find in other IDEs. Unfortunately there does not seem to be an option to do this in a case sensitive manner. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10662489/30513174-34b122aa-9ac4-11e7-8c38-8ea0cd06e3b5.png)

It would be nice if this option could either be configurable to be case sensitive or perhaps to have another shortcut that could function the same as Command D but in a case sensitive manner.

_Copied from original issue: Microsoft/vscode-go#1217_

data.title: Scrolling inertia transfers scrolling when mouse over new scrollable area

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: Windows 10.0.15063

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open 2 windows in vs code that are scrollable
2. Hover mouse over first window
3. Flick mouse scroll wheel to trigger inertia scrolling
3. Move mouse pointer to second window. Second window will start scrolling.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

This may be an OS level feature, but it's really annoying when the second window is the tabs on top that scroll when the mouse gets moved to hover it during inertia scrolling.

![scrolling inertia](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8039397/30523968-ee60d0de-9bb8-11e7-9637-11a2fd314693.gif)

**Edit:** Demo shown using Microsoft Arc Mouse on a Surface Book. Flicked the "scroll wheel" on the mouse once, then proceeded to move the mouse while different windows started scrolling (because of scrolling inertia). Expected result would be to have originating window scroll the whole time no mater where the mouse drifts off to or a new scroll flick is triggered.

data.title: [json] `additionalItems` keyword not validated
Feature request: There's no default formatting for CSS files when pressing shift+alt+f
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro

Steps to Reproduce: 
Just press the default formatting shortcut **shift+alt+f** in a CSS file. You'll notice that the shortcut won't work for it.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Though we can get formatting by using beautify extension but I think every code editor must have CSS formatting in-built. It was quite disappointing. I hope it'll be resolved in coming updates.

data.title: ignoreEOLComments has additional properties
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:23.027Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-color|ans|0.4.5
vscode-eslint|dba|1.3.1
githistory|don|0.2.3
beautify|Hoo|1.1.1
vscode-regexp-preivew|le0|0.0.3
sublime-keybindings|ms-|2.9.1
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.3.0
material-icon-theme|PKi|2.2.1
java|red|0.10.0



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a front-end project
2. Warning come...

Warning text:

> e:\svn\drs-frontend\.eslintrc.yml: Configuration for rule "no-multi-spaces" is invalid: Value "data["0"].ignoreEOLComments" has additional properties.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

***************

My .eslintrc.yml:

```yml
...
  no-magic-numbers: 0

  # 禁止多个空格
  # no-multi-spaces: 0
  no-multi-spaces:
    - 2
    -
      ignoreEOLComments: true
      exceptions:
        Property: true
        VariableDeclarator: true
        ImportDeclaration: true

  # 禁止多行字符串
  no-multi-str: 1

...
```

data.title: Replace bash shebang with '#!/usr/bin/env bash" for portability
data.body: The example system that does not put `bash` in a `/bin` directory is FreeBSD. Instead, they put it inside `/usr/local/bin`.
